snippet: Attacks carried out far from the Islamic State’s base in Iraq and Syria upend the view held by the United States and its allies that the group was a regional threat.
abstract: Terrorist attacks carried out by Islamic State in Paris, Beirut and Egypt represent first results of group's shift in focus to overseas attacks carried out with backing of central leadership; change, upending long-held assumptions about ISIS, may be motivated in party by desire to compete with Al Qaeda for control of global jihad.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Katrin Bennhold from Paris, Anne Barnard and Hwaida Saad from Beirut, Lebanon, and Kimiko De Freytas-Tamura from Brussels. Kitty Bennett contributed research.

lead_paragraph: Attacks carried out far from the Islamic State’s base in Iraq and Syria upend the view held by the United States and its allies that the group was a regional threat.

headline.main: Paris Attacks and Other Assaults Seen as Evidence of a Shift by ISIS
headline.print_headline: Latest Attacks Seen as Evidence of a Shift by ISIS

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
